awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Ian M. Zemke is "Heegard-Floer Invariants of Surfaces and Four-Manifolds." The host institution for the fellowship is Princeton University, and the sponsoring scientist is Peter Ozsvath.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Heegaard Floer homology is a set of groups associated to 3-manifolds which were discovered by Ozsvath and Szabo in the early 2000s. A 3-manifold is a space which has 3 spatial dimensions. To a 3-manifold Y, they associated a group, called the Heegaard Floer homology of Y. To a 4-manifold with two boundary components, they described a map between the Heegaard Floer homologies of the two boundary components. In mathematical terms, this gives a functor from the category of cobordisms to the category of groups.

Their theory satisfied many of the axioms of a TQFT (topological quantum field theory), as described by Atiyah. Nonetheless, there were several restrictions on their theory which prevented it from being a proper TQFT according to Atiyah's axioms. The PI found a framework which extended Ozsvath and Szabo's original construction and fit Heegaard Floer homology into Atiyah's axioms for a TQFT.

The PI used this framework to study low-dimensional topology. Applications include the study of closed 4-manifolds, and new computation of the "mixed invariants" of Ozsvath Szabo. Some of the applications relied heavily on the new TQFT axioms for Heegaard Floer homology, using formulas involving algebraic trace maps.

Additionally, the PI developed other aspects of functoriality in Heegaard Floer theory. The PI developed a theory of functoriality for links and link cobordisms. This extended a previous theory of Juhasz which worked only on the "hat" flavor, which is algebraically restricted. The PI used this theory to prove a number of applications towards important objects of study in low-dimensional topology, such as the concordance group and the homology cobordism group. Many applications came by proving various aspects about the theory of involutive Heegaard Floer homology of Hendricks and Manolescu. The PI with collaborators proved fundamental results, such as connected sum formulas and surgery exact sequences for the involutive theory.

Another important application of the link Floer TQFT has been the discovery of a relationship between knot Floer homology and ribbon concordance. A concordance between two knots K0 and K1 is an embedded annulus in S3x[0,1] which co-bounds the two knots. These are highly studied objects in low-dimensional topology. A ribbon concordance is a concordance which has no local maxima with respect to the natural height function. Ribbon concordances are the subject of many famous conjectures in low-dimensional topology.

Using the link Floer TQFT, the PI proved that the existence of a ribbon concordance from K0 to K1 implies very strong restrictions on the knot Floer homologies of K0 and K1. In particular, it implies that the Floer homology of K0 injects into the Floer homology of K1. This was the first Floer theoretic result concerning ribbon concordances, and the PI used it to prove several purely topological results about knots. Subsequently, various authors including the PI investigated ribbon concordances and Floer theory further, and showed that the phenomon had analogs in virtually every Floer theory and knot homology theory known.

During the grant perioud, the PI mentored several undergraduates, leading to one undergraduate paper on the arXiv. The PI also co-organized a section of a remote conference, as well as seminars at Princeton University.


Last Modified: 12/27/2021
Modified by: Ian M Zemke

Image
  • There is a ribbon concordance from the trefoil on the left to the knot on the right.
    Ian Zemke
    Ian M Zemke
    A ribbon concordance
